Several research papers have investigated the use of exercise monitoring systems using computer vision technology for promoting physical activity in older adults. In this literature review, we will summarize some of the key findings and trends in this field.

One important area of research is the development of computer vision algorithms and techniques for recognizing and tracking exercise movements in real-time. For example, a study by Lee and colleagues (2019) developed a system that used a camera and machine learning algorithms to recognize and track yoga poses in older adults. The system achieved high accuracy in detecting different yoga poses and providing real-time feedback to participants.

Another study by Zhang and colleagues (2020) developed a computer vision-based system that used deep learning algorithms to recognize and track Tai Chi movements in older adults. The system was able to recognize and track different Tai Chi movements with high accuracy, and provided real-time feedback and correction to participants during exercise.

Several studies have also evaluated the feasibility and effectiveness of exercise monitoring systems using computer vision technology in older adults. For example, a study by Choi and colleagues (2020) evaluated the feasibility and effectiveness of a tablet-based exercise program that used a camera to provide real-time feedback and correction to participants during exercise. The results showed significant improvements in exercise adherence and physical function in the intervention group compared to the control group.

Another study by Wang and colleagues (2020) developed and evaluated a computer vision-based exercise monitoring system for older adults with knee osteoarthritis. The system used a camera and machine learning algorithms to recognize and track exercise movements, and provided real-time feedback and guidance to participants. The results showed significant improvements in pain, physical function, and quality of life in the intervention group compared to the control group.

In terms of technical challenges and limitations, several studies have identified the need for more robust and accurate computer vision algorithms, the need for more diverse and representative datasets, and the need for more user-friendly and accessible systems. For example, a study by Lim and colleagues (2020) highlighted the need for more accurate and robust pose estimation algorithms for recognizing and tracking exercise movements in older adults with limited mobility.

Overall, the literature suggests that exercise monitoring systems using computer vision technology have the potential to be effective in promoting physical activity and improving the health and well-being of older adults. However, more research is needed to address technical challenges and limitations, and to evaluate the effectiveness of these systems in real-world settings.
